title: Wednesday, 4th January, 2017
bodyHTML:
11:00 am
PM11:00am

Morning

PM11:01am

Our daily market chat

PM11:01am

We've fixed the delayed start problem

11:01 am
PM11:01am

By starting early!

PM11:01am

And time it so that the tech issues are 'fixed" by 11am

PM11:01am

Kinda genius really

11:02 am
PM11:02am

Leaps and bounds that humanity makes with logical hacks like that

PM11:02am

But for all the focus on getting the session off on time, I've forgotten to line up a pic for today.

PM11:03am

Wanted the bitcoin price, but accidently deleted the tab

11:03 am
PM11:03am

You want to see the abuse some of my close colleagues have been getting overnight for writing negative things on clown finance

PM11:03am

Well, actually you don't want to see it

PM11:04am

Sell Twitter

11:04 am
PM11:04am

Anyway...

undefined
PM11:05am

Footsie becalmed, but that doesn't reflect a storm beneath

11:05 am
BE11:05am

Storm-ish, I guess.

PM11:05am

Yeah, storm-ish

PM11:05am

Shall we go straight to Next or... elsewhere

11:06 am
BE11:06am

I guess with retail. Next's trading-to-Christmas-eve update is the unofficial start to each trading year, so it'd be churlish to ignore it.

BE11:06am

And this one's a bit of a stinker.

Next PLC (NXT:LSE): Last: 4,304, down 466 (-9.77%), High: 4,400, Low: 4,090, Volume: 1.28m
11:06 am
PM11:06am

Indeed. Next is off the bottom, but not a lot off

BE11:07am

So for the 54 days to December 24, Next total full price sales were down 0.4% vs consensus of up 2.2%

BE11:07am

Slightly surprising, perhaps, is that it's the high street side.

11:07 am
BE11:07am

Directories -- ie. the expensive credit business disguised as a catalogue -- did okay.

BE11:08am

But we've had that particular shakeout, with tighter credit standards and cleaner customer lists, etc. Now we're back to bog-ordinary high street trading.

BE11:09am

Which looks like this (via Goldman)

11:08 am
BE11:09am

BE11:10am

You've also got what most of the reports are calling a profit warning for YE 2017

BE11:10am

Which is arguable. The bottom of the range doesn't change, but the top has been stepped down considerably.

11:11 am
PM11:11am

hmm

PM11:11am

Range narrowed to the downside

BE11:11am

Then there's the 2018 warning, which is definitely a warning. But, again, it's arguable whether you can call outer year guidance cuts explicit profit warnings. I had many fights about this while working at newswires.

11:11 am
BE11:11am

Instead of retreading those fights, here's Morgan Stanley.

BE11:12am

Next does not disclose LfL sales, but we calculate that the LfL in its retail division would have been down by around 6% (consensus was looking for c-2%)

BE11:12am

- With less than one (seasonally unimportant) month of its financial year remaining, Next is also today significantly tightening its profit guidance range for FY 2016/17. It now expects Pre Tax Profits to be between £785m and £799m. This
compares with a previous range of £785m-£825m, suggesting that the mid point is falling today by around 1%. According to Bloomberg, consensus is currently expecting Pre Tax Profits of £801m (giving 441p of EPS), so we would expect consensus for the current year to move down marginally today.

11:12 am
BE11:12am

- The bigger downgrades, however, are likely to come to the outer year. Consistent with its approach in previous years, Next has again used its Christmas trading update to provide its first financial guidance for its new financial year.

BE11:12am

The company is forecasting sales to grow in a range of between --4.5% and +1.5%, with a profit guidance range of £680-£780m. According to Bloomberg the current consensus average Pre Tax Profit expectation for FY 2017/18 is around £780m (with a range of £745m-£825m), so the mid point of the new range implies a downgrade of around 7% to consensus forecasts for FY 2017/18

- Based on existing consensus forecasts and last night's closing price, Next is trading on 10.7x Cal 2017 earnings, 8.3x EBITDA with a 3.4% dividend yield. This compares with a UK General Retail sector trading on 12.7x, 7.8x and 3.9% respectively

PM11:13am

(Where's TheLeggie on the right? Haven't seen for a while. He's been a holder of Next pretty much for ever.)

11:13 am
BE11:13am

And here's Exane, which has a long and worthwhile drill down into the statement.

BE11:14am

Uncertainty over Next’s forecast agenda is arguably greater than it has been over that period - management have missed expectations for the year just passed and have left a wide range of guidance. Cash generation is a geared residual of profit generation.

In this context, today doesn’t immediately look to be a “kitchen sinking”. In an environment where we expect total retail sales to be flat, and Next to lose share (catalogue business, mass-market positioning), if clothing continues to underperform retail sales (as management suggest they fear) then the outcome could be materially worse. Every further 1% miss on revenues would likely translate into a c.2% further decline in PBT.

Furthermore management guidance is still predicated on a very limited impact from input cost pressures. This would look to be a best case rather than base case scenario in our opinion, and presents an additoinal headwind of up to c.£60m (c.8% of guided PBT).

BE11:15am

We await to see the trading results of peers, but industry data would not have suggested an outturn this weak (although data did soften in the final couple of weeks).
It maybe [suggests] that market share losses have accelerated.
We would point to;
A potential acceleration in the decline of the catalogue (and credit) business – this is highlighted by the c.5% growth in Directory (vs c.20% growth in online across peak)
 Accelerating losses given a structurally weak position in the mass-market
Market share losses to M&S following as their price cuts begin to gain traction (we wouldn’t get too excited on M&S, there will a gross margin cost to them for this)
 Market share pressures from other brands (such as Supergroup) with stronger momentum, better brand positioning and greater levels of tactical promotion
* Competitor discounting. Next CEO Simon Wolfson seems to be pointing towards this, but this hasn’t been an issue for Next over previous peak trading and industry data would suggest discount rates were if anything lower year-on-year

11:15 am
BE11:15am

(The weird bolding is Exane's bullet points interfering with the Markets Live markup language. It's not intended to suggest significance.)

BE11:16am

In terms of peer readacross ......

BE11:17am

Exane notes probable market share loss, as well as the lack of self-help options because it's already pretty lean and unable to pass through cost inflation by sacking people or whatnot.

11:17 am
BE11:17am

Nevertheless ..........

BE11:17am

For M&S results should be far stronger given the calendar timing benefit and potential market share gains. However, we expect new CEO Steve Rowe will do his best to keep a lid on expectations (although formal outer year guidance is unlikely at this stage, softening any implications from results)
 For Supergroup, momentum looks more robust and a currency tailwind persists. A positive management team enacting lots of change are unlikely to sound as cautious, with a pipeline of self-help initiatives ahead of them
For Ted Baker, the customer dynamic is different, structural market share pressures less relevant and wholesale guidance looks conservative. Forecasts thus look well underpinned, although momentum may not encourage to the extent we had hoped
 For the online retailers, ASOS and Boohoo, we expect continued strong momentum and positive outlook commentary – when growing at 25% + it matters little if the market is a few % weaker (especially when you can switch to driving pent-up demand from overseas countries if necessary)

Marks and Spencer Group PLC (MKS:LSE): Last: 329.05, down 15.45 (-4.48%), High: 335.80, Low: 325.00, Volume: 8.60m

11:21 am

BE11:22am

Lone Pine doesn't really do much in the UK. Also short Burberry and Tesco, I think.

11:25 am

BE11:27am

11:28 am
BE11:28am

And since we can't quite leave retail yet ... B&M.

B&M European Value Retail SA (BME:LSE): Last: 295.20, up 18.2 (+6.57%), High: 298.76, Low: 285.10, Volume: 2.55m
BE11:29am

Reverse profit warning.

11:29 am
BE11:29am

Here's Investec.

BE11:29am

An unscheduled update demonstrates a very strong Christmas trading performance, with growth across both non-food and FMCG. While LFLs are not a key driver of forecasts, in our view they will be a key driver of sentiment given the relatively lacklustre LFL performance over FY16/1H17. We upgrade forecasts by c. 3% this year and next, and see upside risk on numbers should momentum persist. Valuation remains attractive, reflecting strong profit growth and the potential for a 5%+ combined yield. Buy.

BE11:29am

Unscheduled update, a record UK performance with B&M reporting a very strong Q3 performance. UK LFLs +7.2%, and total UK sales +20.5%. Heading into Q4, we note that UK LFLs will face a headwind from Q3’s extra day of trading (c.1%), timing of Easter (c.1%) and ongoing cannibalisation (c.70bps).
Performance strong across categories with c. 2/3 of UK LFL from footfall / transactions and 1/3 by value, with gross margins reassuringly broadly flat.
Update reassures that FY16’s UK issues are falling away in our view, with the strong trading performance benefitting from: 1) lower levels of cannibalisation (-1.2% in Q3 vs. -1.7% in H1); 2) better levels of on-shelf availability from buying; and 3) improved distribution as the company corrected last year’s warehouse problems.
Germany on track with 73 stores open at end-Q3 (INVe 75 for end-FY17e) with sales +18.8% on a Euro basis, and mildly positive LFL performance.
Upgrades relatively modest (c. 3% this year and next) with upside risk in our view, with the improvement in sentiment more significant given B&M’s relatively lacklustre UK LFL performance during FY16/1H17 generating questions over the longevity of the model as it rolled out.
Valuation attractive with potential for material TSR: The shares trade on a CY17e P/E of 18.6x, with a 2% dividend yield and capability to return c. 5%+ if 2016’s special dividend is to be repeated, allowing the business to generate mid-single digit levels of TSR, with the shares trading on 1.4x PE/TSR, pre special dividend (1.1x incl. special). TP increased, reflecting upgrades.

11:30 am
BE11:30am

(@Boncoeur: maybe Jacamo customers wear jeans as shirts. Their niche market is the oddly shaped, isn't it?)

BE11:31am

And Numis ............

BE11:31am

11:31 am
BE11:31am

B&M has reported strong LFL over the Christmas quarter and is confident that it will meet market expectations for FY profit. We expect this to be helpful to sentiment, supporting the proven roll out strategy that remains the main engine of growth. The shares have outperformed the sector but the valuation remains at a clear discount to its real peer group of high-growth European formats at 17x PE to cal-17F.

BE11:31am

And Peel Hunt.

PM11:00am

Welcome to ML

BE11:38am

11:38 am
McCarthy & Stone PLC (MCS:LSE): Last: 164.40, up 5.4 (+3.40%), High: 165.43, Low: 162.20, Volume: 459.67k
BE11:38am

[ MEANDER WARNING ]

BE11:39am

I was chatting to a McCarthy & Stone resident over Christmas, who was complaining a lot ......

11:39 am
BE11:39am

.... apparently, their complex is being filled up by young people.

BE11:39am

BE11:40am

Who all drive meaning the parking spaces they'd been promised for family to visit are no longer there.

11:41 am
BE11:41am

And who all like to impose rules and regulations on the geniunely old ........ It sounded a wee bit like being a mature student in University digs.

BE11:41am

[/MEANDER WARNING]

BE11:42am

Let me grab is Deutsche thing.

11:42 am
BE11:42am

(@Mouselet: yep. Geriatric care in this country is a scandal.)

BE11:43am

After a tumultuous 2016, we see appealing value in the UK Housebuilder
sector. While investor appetite for UK focused stocks remains more moderated
reflecting Brexit risk, we see dividend yield as difficult to ignore and believe
trading updates should continue to reassure on strong cash flow generation
and ROCE greater than 25%. While macro events (timing and extent of EU exit, UK
economic progression, govt housing policy) may create share price volatility,
particularly through Q1 16, we believe the sector offers opportunity for 30%
upside. Our top pick is Taylor Wimpey.

BE11:43am

On our updated forecasts our price targets suggest close to 30% upside across the sector as a whole and as such we maintain our positive stance on the UK Housebuilders. While recognising the sector trades relatively homogeneously (and our buys reflect relative preference rather than a negative view of the others), we maintain our buys on Taylor Wimpey, Barratt and Berkeley Group. We add McCarthy & Stone to that list upgrading the recommendation to Buy seeing strong value. We have downgraded Bovis to Hold reflecting the continued operational stutters which have impacted confidence in forecasts.

11:43 am
BE11:44am

With both the UK economy and housing market appearing to largely shrug off the impact of the Brexit vote, we have adjusted our assumptions for the UK housebuilding sector for 2017 onwards (flat selling rates and pricing). This has resulted in significant increases in DB ests (100%+ in 2017, 50%+ in 2018, 20%+ in 2019) - a return of forecasts close to those we held pre-Brexit.

BE11:44am

On P/NTAV the UK Housebuilders now trade at 1.3x 2017/ 1.2x 2018, which with the sector achieving ROCE up to 3x its cost of capital, we believe overplays the risk to future earnings. For those within the FTSE100 (Barratt, Persimmon, Taylor Wimpey) we also see dividend yield underpinning valuation. Few alternative stocks in the index offer dividend yields greater than 6.5%, which are covered by FCF with scope for more should the companies look to return their full net cash.

BE11:45am

With new ministers in charge of Housing, we see increasing risk that government continues to dabble in the sector and the Housing White Paper in January could impact sentiment (perhaps more so than any impact on earnings). However, we believe any weakness in share prices around this time should be used as a buying opportunity with the sector likely to demonstrate steady reassurance through the year with its continuous cycle of trading updates.

11:45 am
BE11:45am

We value the UK Housebuilders primarily on P/NTAV and for those with significant dividend yields adding into the mix the valuation implied by to 5%. in the sector. Our price target changes reflect the balance of higher earnings estimates to some extent offset by a 2ppt increase in discount rates used on NTAV to reflect the increased risk in the sector. Risks include: the availability & affordability of mortgages, competition in the land, BoE interest rate, unemployment.

BE11:47am

Have a chart too.

BE11:47am

11:47 am
BE11:48am

Actually, have three more. London centric.

BE11:48am

BE11:48am

(Right click open new window to see properly.)

11:49 am
BE11:49am

As in, London's boned but it matters very little to the sector, because the cartel is still a cartel.

BE11:49am

o 2020 we anticipate approx 160,000 housing completions in England, close to the level we anticipated pre Brexit. However with the ‘change in housing supply’ reported by industry bodies now including conversions and non registered new builds, this implies that the industry ‘meets’ the government target of 200,000 by 2020

BE11:49am

DB ests do not include a significant pick up affordable homes (either in terms of council built homes as proposed by Opposition leader Corbyn, nor affordable driven by change in build method ie pre fabricated homes). We believe that the occupiers of these homes are generally not those purchasing homes or driving house price inflation.

Aberdeen Asset Management PLC (ADN:LSE): Last: 271.75, up 1.05 (+0.39%), High: 274.40, Low: 270.20, Volume: 710.93k
11:52 am

Whole sector's been doing okay, and Aberdeen was an underperformer through December on expectations of a dividend cut.

BE11:52am

The FX tailwind might mitigate that.

BE11:54am

And since we're wrapping up old stuff ......

11:54 am
BE11:54am

@Lefevre mentions Odey.

BE11:55am

In case you missed his December letter to (a diminishing pool of) investors, Bloomberg summarises: https://www.bloomb...lled-fund-managers

BE11:55am

Odey Sees ‘Mindless’ Investing Driving Out Skilled Fund Managers

11:55 am
BE11:55am

Crispin Odey, whose flagship hedge fund is on course to record its worst year since starting more than two decades ago, said money managers specializing in picking stocks and bonds are being driven out by “mindless” passive investing.

“This has been a difficult year for active managers,” Odey said in his November newsletter to investors, which has been seen by Bloomberg News. “Passive investing has taken money which typically would have been in the bond market and deposited it in the equity market.”

BE11:56am

Or, to put it another way .....

BE11:56am

11:56 am
BE11:56am

Thumbs up

undefined
BE11:56am

@Blue horseshoe mentions M&A grift .......

11:57 am
BE11:57am

The answer is "not much. I note that Ben H wrote up the Michael Kors story on December 31.

BE11:57am

https://betaville....ke-a-deal-in-2017/

BE11:58am

.... a story we spent approximately three months and many, many, many reporting hours trying to pin down.

11:59 am
BE11:59am

I've nothing to add to what Ben's written, other than to say we heard much the same and couldn't get it to the point where we would be comfortable writing anything whatsoever.

BE12:01pm

There's also an Australian story on the notepad, and a US pharma one, but both are in similar points of reporting limbo. And as we really could do without people throwing around accusations of "fake news" (sigh), that's where they'll be staying for now.

BE12:01pm

Sorry.

12:01 pm
undefined
BE12:02pm

Oh, that's midday. Anything to round up on?

BE12:03pm

There are drugs. JPM has its 2017 drugs preview out.

12:03 pm
BE12:03pm

Generally positive on everything, apart from Circassia.

BE12:03pm

arge-caps: Shire remains our top pick, though we remove it from the AFL
our AFL thesis having played out in terms of 2016 catalysts, albeit without
the re-rating we believe is deserved. With Shire trading only 9x 2018e PE,
valuation remains compelling. GSK is our second choice, we see the
dividend secure, and consensus forecasts well underpinned even with timely
generic Advair approval; however, there are limited catalysts, and the
valuation look fair rather than compelling. Astra is our least preferred,
heading into the imminent MYSTIC immuno-oncology trial read-out, where
we see high hurdles for success. We see more attractive risk/reward around
the rest of the pipeline; hence, we will reassess post MYSTIC headlines.

BE12:04pm

SMid-caps: Vectura is our top pick, given significant upside from generic
Advair approval, and the base business alone justifying the current share-
price. Hikma remains an Overweight, around generic Advair upside, which
could drive significant upgrades for 2018 and beyond. This is despite the
fact that we see downside to Branded business to LC weakness and further
FX headwinds. BTG we remain Neutral, as although we see a strong topline
performance for Interventional Medicine, we still see some downside to
consensus expectations for 2018 and beyond, M&A needed to sustain the
double digit topline aspiration. Circassia downgrade to Neutral, as after
taking a more conservative view on the generics business, and after recent
outperformance, our Embedded value highlights only modest upside.

12:04 pm
BE12:05pm

Just spinning through the note, its summary of AZN's year is a bracing read.

BE12:05pm

(1) Brilinta failed in both SOCRATES stroke and EUCLID PAD Phase III studies; (2) Durvalumab HAWK and CONDOR Head & Neck cancer data was insufficient for filing; (3) Tremelimumab DETERMINE Mesothelioma study failed; (4) Lynparza GOLD Gastric cancer study failed; (5) ZS-9 received a complete response letter, as opposed to approval.

BE12:05pm

So why are we so optimistic about Mystic?

12:06 pm
BE12:06pm

We maintain our cautious view on the chances of success for MYSTIC, Astra’s 1st-
line Lung immuno-oncology study, as we continue to see a significant risk that
Astra’s PD-L1/CTLA-4 immuno-oncology combo isn’t statistically superior to PD-1
mono in PD-L1 high expression patients (Merck monotherapy data looks a high bar),
and we also see a risk that the combo isn’t statistically superior to chemotherapy in the PD-L1 low expression patients (where chemo works well). Recent comments from Astra on their December R&D call that they are more confident in success using an Overall Survival metric (reporting in 2018) as opposed to the Progression
Free Survival metric (reporting in H1 2017), do not increase our confidence in positive data in H1 2017. In addition, company comments that, for the PD-L1 high expression population, monotherapy may be the best option makes us increasingly cautious on whether the combo will show superiority to mono in this population, and
whether in the absence of a significant combo benefit, whether the study will be sufficient to generate a mono approval, with combo being the primary.

BE12:06pm

MYSTIC sensitivity analysis finds Astra could be up as much as 30% to c.£55 with a best-case MYSTIC outcome (success across PD-L1 high and low patients) with the stock still having the potential to fall 20%, to c.£35 upon MYSTIC failure.

BE12:06pm

.... ah, but you know my views on I-O already. Let's wind up.

12:06 pm
AstraZeneca PLC (AZN:LSE): Last: 4,497, up 58 (+1.31%), High: 4,499, Low: 4,443, Volume: 479.07k
GlaxoSmithKline PLC (GSK:LSE): Last: 1,573, up 10.5 (+0.67%), High: 1,573, Low: 1,556, Volume: 1.68m
Shire PLC (SHP:LSE): Last: 4,797, up 37 (+0.78%), High: 4,810, Low: 4,765, Volume: 352.75k
12:07 pm
undefined
BE12:07pm

Ta for joining. Ta for the comments. Back tomorrow.

BE11:32am

Christmas trading was way above the market (and possibly B&M’s expectations), with LFL returning to pre-IPO levels (7.2%). We do not see any reason why B&M wouldn’t continue to win lots of market share, across retail and within the discount sector, and pleasingly, the upbeat rhetoric on margins going forward is retained. We are top of the range and will resist the temptation to upgrade further: consensus will have to rise though and we do not see this as a one-off. Here is a business with serious momentum, in the right part of the retail sector with strong management and an overseas plan. Not to mention the possibility (probability?) of another special. This is a must for pretty much any type of fund right now: Buy to 440p.
